natural problem: The Grammar club has 20 members: 10 boys and 10 girls.  A 4-person committee is chosen at random.  What is the probability that the committee has at least 1 boy and at least 1 girl?
natural solution: The number of ways to choose a committee of all boys or all girls is $2\times\binom{10}{4}=420$. The total number of committees is $\binom{20}{4}=4845$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boys girls total_committees committee_with_at_least_one_boy_and_girl :: real
assumes h0 : "boys = 10"
and h1 : "girls = 10"
and h2 : "total_committees = nCr (boys + girls) 4"
and h3 : "committee_with_at_least_one_boy_and_girl = total_committees - (nCr boys 4 + nCr girls 4)"
and h4 : "nCr m n = fact m / (fact n * fact (m - n))"
shows  "committee_with_at_least_one_boy_and_girl / total_committees = 295 / 323"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grammar club has 20 members: 10 boys and 10 girls.  A 4-person committee is chosen at random.  What is the probability that the committee has at least 1 boy and at least 1 girl? The final Answer is \dfrac{295}{323}
 ### Proof
 The number of ways to choose a committee of all boys or all girls is $2\times\binom{10}{4}=420$. The total number of committees is $\binom{20}{4}=4845$.
 Thus the answer is $1-\dfrac{420}{4845} = \dfrac{4425}{4845} = \boxed{\dfrac{295}{323}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes boys girls total_committees committee_with_at_least_one_boy_and_girl :: real
assumes h0 : "boys = 10"
and h1 : "girls = 10"
and h2 : "total_committees = nCr (boys + girls) 4"
and h3 : "committee_with_at_least_one_boy_and_girl = total_committees - (nCr boys 4 + nCr girls 4)"
and h4 : "nCr m n = fact m / (fact n * fact (m - n))"
shows  "committee_with_at_least_one_boy_and_girl / total_committees = 295 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a group of 10 boys and 10 girls, a committee of 4 members is to be formed. What is the probability that the committee has at least one boy and one girl? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{295}{323}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boys girls committees :: nat
assumes h0 : "boys = 10"
and h1 : "girls = 10"
and h2 : "committees = 20 choose 4"
and h3 : "295 / 323 = (committees - (boys choose 4) - (girls choose 4)) / committees"
shows  "295 / 323 = (committees - (boys choose 4) - (girls choose 4)) / committees"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grammar club has 20 members: 10 boys and 10 girls.  A 4-person committee is chosen at random.  What is the probability that the committee has at least 1 boy and at least 1 girl? The final Answer is \dfrac{295}{323}
 ### Proof
 The number of ways to choose a committee of all boys or all girls is $2\times\binom{10}{4}=420$. The total number of committees is $\binom{20}{4}=4845$.
 Thus the answer is $1-\dfrac{420}{4845} = \dfrac{4425}{4845} = \boxed{\dfrac{295}{323}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes boys girls committees :: nat
assumes h0 : "boys = 10"
and h1 : "girls = 10"
and h2 : "committees = 20 choose 4"
and h3 : "295 / 323 = (committees - (boys choose 4) - (girls choose 4)) / committees"
shows  "295 / 323 = (committees - (boys choose 4) - (girls choose 4)) / committees"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a group, there are 10 boys and 10 girls. A committee of 4 members is to be formed from this group. What is the probability that the committee will have at least one boy and one girl? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{295}{323}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_committee :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P_committee = (binomial 20 4 - binomial 10 4 - binomial 10 4) / binomial 20 4"
shows  "P_committee = 295 / 323"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grammar club has 20 members: 10 boys and 10 girls.  A 4-person committee is chosen at random.  What is the probability that the committee has at least 1 boy and at least 1 girl? The final Answer is \dfrac{295}{323}
 ### Proof
 The number of ways to choose a committee of all boys or all girls is $2\times\binom{10}{4}=420$. The total number of committees is $\binom{20}{4}=4845$.
 Thus the answer is $1-\dfrac{420}{4845} = \dfrac{4425}{4845} = \boxed{\dfrac{295}{323}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P_committee :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P_committee = (binomial 20 4 - binomial 10 4 - binomial 10 4) / binomial 20 4"
shows  "P_committee = 295 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a committee of 20 people, 10 are women and 10 are men. Find the probability that a randomly chosen subcommittee of 4 members does not consist of only women or only men. Express your answer as a common fraction. The final answer is $\frac{295}{323}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>(i::nat)\<in>{1..9}. (\<Sum>(j::nat)\<in>{1..10}. (10 choose i) * (10 choose j))) / (20 choose 4)"
shows  "probability = 295 / 323"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grammar club has 20 members: 10 boys and 10 girls.  A 4-person committee is chosen at random.  What is the probability that the committee has at least 1 boy and at least 1 girl? The final Answer is \dfrac{295}{323}
 ### Proof
 The number of ways to choose a committee of all boys or all girls is $2\times\binom{10}{4}=420$. The total number of committees is $\binom{20}{4}=4845$.
 Thus the answer is $1-\dfrac{420}{4845} = \dfrac{4425}{4845} = \boxed{\dfrac{295}{323}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<Sum>(i::nat)\<in>{1..9}. (\<Sum>(j::nat)\<in>{1..10}. (10 choose i) * (10 choose j))) / (20 choose 4)"
shows  "probability = 295 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the probability of selecting exactly 4 items from a set of 20 items, such that you pick at least one from the first group of 10 items and at least one from the second group of 10 items. Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{295}{323}$.

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (binomial 20 4 - binomial 10 4 - binomial 10 4) / binomial 20 4"
shows  "P = 295 / 323"

 Thus the answer is $1-\dfrac{420}{4845} = \dfrac{4425}{4845} = \boxed{\dfrac{295}{323}}$.

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (binomial 20 4 - binomial 10 4 - binomial 10 4) / binomial 20 4"

a_4.informal problem: A committee of 20 people is to be formed by choosing 4 members from a group of 10 men and another group of 10 women. Calculate the probability $P$ that the committee contains an equal number of men and women. The final answer is $\frac{295}{323}$.

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (binomial 20 4 - binomial 10 4 - binomial 10 4) / binomial 20 4"
shows  "probability = 295 / 323"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grammar club has 20 members: 10 boys and 10 girls.  A 4-person committee is chosen at random.  What is the probability that the committee has at least 1 boy and at least 1 girl? The final Answer is \dfrac{295}{323}
 ### Proof
 The number of ways to choose a committee of all boys or all girls is $2\times\binom{10}{4}=420$. The total number of committees is $\binom{20}{4}=4845$.
 Thus the answer is $1-\dfrac{420}{4845} = \dfrac{4425}{4845} = \boxed{\dfrac{295}{323}}$.

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (binomial 20 4 - binomial 10 4 - binomial 10 4) / binomial 20 4"

a_5.informal problem: In a set of 20 items, there are $\binom{20}{4}$ ways to choose 4 items. If 10 of the items are of type A and 10 are of type B, there are $\binom{10}{4}$ ways to choose 4 items of type A and $\binom{10}{4}$ ways to choose 4 items of type B. What is the probability of choosing a combination of 4 items that contains at least one item from each type? The final answer is $\frac{295}{323}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boys girls total_members committee_members :: nat
and prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "boys = 10"
and h1 : "girls = 10"
and h2 : "total_members = boys + girls"
and h3 : "committee_members = 4"
and h4 : "prob = (nCr (total_members - 1) (committee_members - 1)) / nCr total_members committee_members"
shows  "prob = 295 / 323"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grammar club has 20 members: 10 boys and 10 girls.  A 4-person committee is chosen at random.  What is the probability that the committee has at least 1 boy and at least 1 girl? The final Answer is \dfrac{295}{323}
 ### Proof
 The number of ways to choose a committee of all boys or all girls is $2\times\binom{10}{4}=420$. The total number of committees is $\binom{20}{4}=4845$.
 Thus the answer is $1-\dfrac{420}{4845} = \dfrac{4425}{4845} = \boxed{\dfrac{295}{323}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes boys girls total_members committee_members :: nat
and prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "boys = 10"
and h1 : "girls = 10"
and h2 : "total_members = boys + girls"
and h3 : "committee_members = 4"
and h4 : "prob = (nCr (total_members - 1) (committee_members - 1)) / nCr total_members committee_members"
shows  "prob = 295 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: In a group of 10 boys and 10 girls, a committee of 4 members is to be formed. What is the probability that a particular boy is included in the committee? The final answer is $\frac{295}{323}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes boys girls committee_members :: nat
assumes h0 : "boys = 10"
and h1 : "girls = 10"
and h2 : "committee_members = 4"
shows  "probability_at_least_one_boy_and_one_girl = (295 / 323)"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grammar club has 20 members: 10 boys and 10 girls.  A 4-person committee is chosen at random.  What is the probability that the committee has at least 1 boy and at least 1 girl? The final Answer is \dfrac{295}{323}
 ### Proof
 The number of ways to choose a committee of all boys or all girls is $2\times\binom{10}{4}=420$. The total number of committees is $\binom{20}{4}=4845$.
 Thus the answer is $1-\dfrac{420}{4845} = \dfrac{4425}{4845} = \boxed{\dfrac{295}{323}}$.

fixes boys girls committee_members :: nat

shows  "probability_at_least_one_boy_and_one_girl = (295 / 323)"

a_7.informal problem: In a group of 10 boys and 10 girls, a committee of 4 members is to be selected. What is the probability that the committee will have at least one boy and one girl? The final answer is $\frac{295}{323}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "probability = (295 / 323)"
shows  "probability = (card {committee. size committee = 4 \<and> (\<exists> boy girl. boy \<in> boys \<and> girl \<in> girls \<and> boy \<in> committee \<and> girl \<in> committee)} / card {committee. size committee = 4 \<and> (\<forall> x \<in> committee. x \<in> boys \<union> girls)})"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grammar club has 20 members: 10 boys and 10 girls.  A 4-person committee is chosen at random.  What is the probability that the committee has at least 1 boy and at least 1 girl? The final Answer is \dfrac{295}{323}
 ### Proof
 The number of ways to choose a committee of all boys or all girls is $2\times\binom{10}{4}=420$. The total number of committees is $\binom{20}{4}=4845$.
 Thus the answer is $1-\dfrac{420}{4845} = \dfrac{4425}{4845} = \boxed{\dfrac{295}{323}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "rat"
assumes h0 : "probability = (295 / 323)"
shows  "probability = (card {committee. size committee = 4 \<and> (\<exists> boy girl. boy \<in> boys \<and> girl \<in> girls \<and> boy \<in> committee \<and> girl \<in> committee)} / card {committee. size committee = 4 \<and> (\<forall> x \<in> committee. x \<in> boys \<union> girls)})"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A committee of 4 people is to be chosen from a group of boys and girls. The probability that a committee contains at least one boy and one girl is $\frac{295}{323}$. What is the probability of forming such a committee, expressed as a fraction?

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>p. p \<ge> 0 \<and> p \<le> 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>p. probability p = (10 choose p) * (10 choose (4 - p)) / (20 choose 4)"
and h2 : "probability 0 = 0"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>p. probability p) {1..3} = 295 / 323"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The Grammar club has 20 members: 10 boys and 10 girls.  A 4-person committee is chosen at random.  What is the probability that the committee has at least 1 boy and at least 1 girl? The final Answer is \dfrac{295}{323}
 ### Proof
 The number of ways to choose a committee of all boys or all girls is $2\times\binom{10}{4}=420$. The total number of committees is $\binom{20}{4}=4845$.
 Thus the answer is $1-\dfrac{420}{4845} = \dfrac{4425}{4845} = \boxed{\dfrac{295}{323}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>p. p \<ge> 0 \<and> p \<le> 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>p. probability p = (10 choose p) * (10 choose (4 - p)) / (20 choose 4)"
and h2 : "probability 0 = 0"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>p. probability p) {1..3} = 295 / 323"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: There is a probability function $p(x)$, where $0 \le x \le 1$, defined as $p(x) = \frac{\binom{10}{x} \cdot \binom{10}{4-x}}{\binom{20}{4}}$. Given that the probability of 0 is 0, find the sum of the probabilities for 1, 2, and 3. The final answer is $\frac{295}{323}$.
